comments.text:
Price of 4090?
Price of 5090?
5080 is wildly overclockable.
It's actually quite a good gpu for the Price. 
I own one. Ive overclocked it (air cooled PC) and using superposition bench it's 260fps with a score of 29800.
Not bad for a 1000 pound gpu.
As a comparison the 9070xt clocked 165fps on same 4k optimised bench.
Just some facts I thought id share.

o7 chaps

comments.text:
Thanks the video

Also similar to my observations as owner of both the 4090 and 5080.    In short, the 5090 really is my only option to improve the performance on Triple 4K 144hz sim rig but no way am I going to throw away money like that.  A$7000  is the RRP for a 5090  my local computer shops, that's the cost of my elderst's first car!!


This is not inflation, this is hyper inflation or monopolistic behaviour.

Before you guys waste your money on a 5080:

1. DLSS 4 and MFG are key for this generation, make sure your games actually use DLSS 4 and MFG.   Most of mine don't....
2. Check out some YT benchmark on the 5080 at native AA (sadly i didnt) for your game & resolution.  If it is under 60fps at native AA setting, MFG is good as poo.
3. 572.70 drivers seems to have made DLSS and MFG work a bit better, at least in some games.  
4. Black Myth at max settings with DLSS on Quality + FG turned on in 4K.  unplayable on the 5080 and 60-70fps.
5.  Kingdom Come Deliverance 2 and Horizon Forbidden West runs smooth great at 4K, way above 100fps
6. U might be better off dropping from Ultra to High and using DLSS Balanced with FG (if supported) at x2.  
7. Less mucking around with the last gen GPU.... less time spent on setting and less compromises.

Here is what I have today

- Sim Racing:  4090 + 9800x3D + Triple 4K 144hz VA  @ 11520x2160 / Pimax Crystal VR 2880x2880 per eye 
- Work and Play: 5080 + 7800x3D + 3840 x 2160 240hz OLED for work and play)

comments.text:
this is like the Geforce GTS 9000 series back in the day. the legendary 8000 series was so good , they just repackaged it into the 9000 series with direct equivilants  GTS 8800 = GTS9800 , GTS 8600 =GTS 9600 , GTS 8400 = GTS 9400 (or was it 8500 , long time ago i forget) .  they are doing the same thing here  classic ngreedia but witha  bit extra wicked twist , the chips for teh 5000 are actually one class lower than their name  and they are jsut matching performance  for the name. with the exception fot eh 5090 of course.

i don';t trust that there wil  be a card to fill the void between the 5080 adn 5090.  there was a pretty god damn big void between the 4080 and the 4090 and the 4080 Super didn't even dent that void . it's clear Nvidia doesn't want to fill that void, and your dreaming bro if you think there's actualy room for them to do so . sure it looks like it could ahve a model sloted in there, but they WILL NEVER FILL IT in a classical sense.  such a card would cost them to much to produce for the price cut it'd have to take to make sense to customers.   the only thing that void exist for is so they can do a cut down Chinese version if the US goverment blocks them releasing the full card in china.


as some one that bought a 4080 Super 7 months ago (and at MSRP no less)  i have zero interest in this abysmal "upgrade".  and here we were thinking Nvidia was about to blow our old systems into the stone age.... instead of a nuclear blast all i hear is a "wonk wonk wonk"  ... playing.  yeah this 4080 super will serve me for a time.

Someone needs to investigate Blackwell's even worse CPU overhead..

This doesn't just affect lower resolution; it affects 3D rendered CPU performance overall, which is 99% the case in anything like emulation, and has nothing really to do using a budget CPU either (ie 5950x).

Anyway.. as per usual, a new generations of hardware are getting worse and worse as Moore's law continues to fall into obscurity.  Having to hold on another 2 years until the next generation of CPUs/GPU's in hopes of better price:performance (and features, especially on motherboards) always sucks.

comments.text:
I did some crunching of numbers based on Time Spy Extreme median graphics scores and MSRPs of various nVidia cards and found that the 5080 only offered 27% better price/performance in over 4 years compared to the 3080. 

It did offer 40% price performance over the hideously priced 4080 (which should have had a $849 MSRP IMO).

The 4080 (16GB) offered 8% worse price/performance for a new gen compared to the 3080 - that's how hideous it was. 

The 3080 gave 72% better price performance over the 2080 alone , and 121% over the 1080. 

Stagnation is definitely a thing (as well as inflation which these numbers don't account for)

comments.text:
So, this year we get the NEW: 4090 Ti, 4080 Ti(...ish), 4070 Ti Super+, the 4070 Super+
I think the 5070 Ti going down in price by about 6% makes it the only card which is most likely to offer a value uplift in $/frame which may achieve 2-percentile digits.
Looking at the specs (pre-reviews), I was kinda hoping that the GDDR7 might help a bit more.

Also, the 7900XTX (and some other 7-series) left a bit of performance on the table due to the infinity fabric being the weakest link. Basically 10% unrealized performance (in the form of max clock) for the primary GPU chip itself. I kinda think AMD should have made a refresh with some fabric improvements, added some RT cores, and launched a very competitive card with very minimal silicon architecture R&D.

Nvidia disappoints yet again but what can you expect when they basically have a monopoly over the gpu market. Very sad to see.

Also a bit off topic here but looking at the Marvel's Spider Man Remastered results I was wondering if anyone would know why my RX 7900XT is having weird issues with this game. When I started playing it with the 7900XT I maxed out everything at 1440p except RT (I set it off). Also FSR and upscaling off. I didn't see FPS drops under 90 (which is still pretty weak in this game) but the game stuttered feeling like it was 40 fps. I tweaked all the settings and what I found was that when I set texture quality to high or very high, the FPS tanks and the stuttering starts. When I have everything maxed out but texture quality on medium, I reach my refresh rate of 165 hz easily without any FPS drops. Even with RT on high quality I get 120-150 FPS. The game also gives me a warning on lauch that "Your 7900XT isn't running on newest drivers, install the newest drivers etc" even though I do have the newest drivers installed. Any idea why is this happening? Other games run well and as expected

comments.text: It is so strange to review the blackwell cards and not make use of the incredible software feature set of these cards and fully explore them as part of your review. In the real world things like DLSS will be used to provide significant performance gains and it seems like because NVIDIA is the only company that has such a compelling set of software solutions to improve frame rates while maintaining image quality those features aren't fully explored in the review of the card itself. I get that this card isn't a huge jump in horsepower from the 4080/4080S but how do those cards compare to 5080 when both are running the transformer based DLSS 4? How does image quality compare? Anecdotally it seems that the new DLSS 4 performance preset in the transformer model exceeds the image quality of DLSS 3 quality and we already know that DLSS 3 was hugely more capable than FSR 3. It seems like the apples to apples comparison that many tech channels rely on to provide context between GPUs is actually failing to acknowledge the full picture of what each GPU brings to the table. If the RTX 5080 is able to use DLSS 4 to provide an image that is effectively indistinguishable from native 4k rendering shouldn't that practical improvement be recognized by a review? It seems to me that the evolution of GPUs is highlighting the limitations of the current batch of bar graph comparisons that tech channels have relied on for so long to document improvements in rasterization capabilities. Food for thought.

comments.text: 13:50 that 7900XTX number for Metro Exodus EE is very surprising to me. On my 7900XTX Bazzite machine I use Extreme graphics, RT Normal, Hybrid Reflections and Tesselation and the lowest dips in framerate I've seen at 4k in 10 hours of gameplay were around 55 fps.  Maybe it's because hairworks was broken on linux when I played a bit last year so I never bothered turning it on?  I know PhysX can also hit performance disproportionately hard for what it does on Linux/AMD so I've had that turned off as well.  Maybe the open source Linux drivers are just better for this game's RT pipeline than Adrenalin?  Regardless, I've been playing with equivalent or higher settings than Steve's benchmark apart from those hairworks and PhysX and getting at minimum 10% higher frames usually closer to 20-25%.  I had vsync disabled (I'm playing on a flatscreen TV with no vrr so 60 is the highest that'suseful) and was getting 65-75 frames when I first started playing and was validating my settings.
comments.author: @wctgttm

comments.text: Oh, I also have to factor in that I have the vram oc'd to 21 gbps.  Combined with the settings differences, that probably makes up a lot of the disparity with Steve's results.
comments.author: @wctgttm

comments.text:
Reminds me of some of the 6000 series AMD cards that were better or nearly the same as the 7000 series. I had said then--why don't they just remanufacture the lower end like they did back with the old R9 models. I guess we could say they did. I only wonder if there are real differences that just don't matter or are salient for gaming. Memory bandwidth is great for AI and GPU virtualization partitions (VDI), but has a massive falloff for gaming since there's less context switching. The same is true for traditional rendering in the professional space. 

So that takes us to the Tensor cores, but as Steve at Gamer's Nexus pointed out: "We don't do AI benchmarks." And his point lands home with a double punch--there's no point to the price of these cards. They aren't new per se, and anything new isn't useful anyway. 

It's stuff like this that makes me glad Nvidia is taking a shellacking in their stock "value" and makes me loathe the hype train/fanboism that leads to people camping in front of retailers in a shameless display of corporate worship.

comments.text:
I planned to purchase one of these as part of a new build to update and upgrade from an 8 year old 1080 PC. 
The reality of buying one of these in Australia is that I could buy an available 4080 super for $1700, or one of these 5080 for a projected $2400-$3000 AUD with a high risk of limited, if any, supply as no founders edition at $2K AUD would be available for purchase. So as I began to see the 4080 super stock just starting to move and be sold, I had to make the move and secure a 4080 super for my system ahead of having no high end graphics card at all, and save myself several hundred or more dollars. And it seems that a stock of many 4080s has almost sold out in a just a week. 
Phew, my assessment that the this 5080 is a mild improvement over the 4080 super may be justified as I will be using it mostly for Blender and productivity, not gaming. So fps and this frame generation is not important at all to me, only raw power of which the 5080 seems to  not have a great advantage over the 4080 super.
But this seems to be Nvidia's strategy in recent times. Introduce high end GPUs at a very limited supply with mild improvements so as to sell out old stock and keep the retailers happy, while selling these (and the 5090) to those that have money to waste . Then introduce the real 5080 after 12 months time as a 5080 super or Ti with more memory and some increased performance as the 5080s sit on shelves and do not move. 
Then for the next generation, if there is one, rinse, wash, repeat.
 In AUD, the 5080 and 5090, just not worth the bother unless one needs them to earn a living.

comments.text: Nvidia have taught us to eat crumbs directly out of their hands and to pay for the privilege. And some of us actually say 'thankyou'. We are getting older, but are we getting any wiser - surely we all know their playbook by now. If we can't wait, we buy the most paired down version that just barely can call itself an 80 series card. If we can wait, we get a Ti or Super version (or both) that is closer to what the original should have been, but this version is timed to maximise profits just ahead of the launch of a new generation. You have gotta love (I actually mean hate) that Nvidia only puts 16GB of VRAM on this 80 series card - deliberately shortening its lifespan. And now we have DLSS 4 trickery to paper over decreasing generational improvements in raster. There might be an actual limit to what you can get silicon to do and so most new improvements and innovations will be software based rather than hardware based - have we finally entered a new paradigm?

comments.text:
It is a minor hardware refresh (PCIe 5.0, real DP 2.1), with some new software features.
People should have been expecting that considering it is the same process node. As if we didn't learn anything from the smartphone market over the last ten years. If you want to know when major performance upgrades will be happening you need to look at the roadmap of TSMC, not Nvidia.

Also it is getting harder and harder to take the comparison with the 7900 XTX seriously. While yes they offer somewhat similar raw performance in rasterization, the moment you activate upscaling, which most people do with modern games the situation completely changes. Even with the latest CNN model DLSS balanced often is on par with FSR 3.1 quality. And now with the transformer model it gets even worse, with DLSS performance beating out FSR 3.1 quality. With those settings a 5080 is not just 15% faster, but more like 50%. And this wont improve for AMD users with FSR 4 only coming to their new cards.

comments.text:
@ Well, I blame AMD marketing and their initial pricing. 7900 XT could've been a best seller from the start. They decided to price it at 900 USD instead of 700 USD for some reason. Now that it's at 700 USD it is selling MUCH better than at the start of the gen. I dislike AMD's short sight behavior. They are trying to make +20% more in the short term, instead of making 50% more by moving more cards in the mid-long term. They ended up selling 7900 XT at 700 USD anyway, so why did they try to sell it at 900 USD initially? Greed and incompetence is the answer. Their engineers are doing their best and are actually producing very capable cards - there is no denying that. But no amount of engineering prowess can compensate for the incompetent marketing department and execs. RDNA2 and RDNA3 were competitive with RTX 3000 and RTX 4000, despite having a fraction of the R&D budget of Nvidia AND the worst marketing in existence. At this point AMD probably stands for "Awful Marketing Department".
It's the same with 7900 XTX too - they could've placed it at 850 USD and everyone and their mothers would've bought it. Imagine having a card 5% faster than 4080 with 8GB more VRAM and 350 USD cheaper. You'd be losing money by not buying it! And they still ended up selling them for 800-850 USD at the end of the day. So why not price them properly???? Not to mention that 7900 XTX and XT were the best selling 7000 series cards by a decent margin and they decided to axe exactly that part of their stack for RDNA4. AMD simply makes blunder after blunder. Watch them announce 9070 XT for 700 USD just for it to not sell at all and then lower the price to 550-500 USD eventually. This will be the most AMD thing to do. I hate their execs and marketing beyond what's reasonable, but I respect their engineers.

comments.text:
The 50 series clearly isn't a practical upgrade for 40 series owners, which you kind of should known before it was even released. 40 series wasn't practical for 30 series, it in turn wasn't practical for 20 series owners, which in turn wasn't practical for 10 series owners, and so on. It's just not how the tech works typically (the 3090 to 4090 was a notable exception), yet we for some reason expect that to change, and I'm not sure why. I think that's why these reviews end up coming across as mostly negative in feeling, because we're comparing to the last generation and expecting... I don't know. 

So why would they release the 50 series at all? Because the vast majority of gamers aren't using 40 series cards, they're using 30 series or older, for which these cards actually are a decent upgrade. We forget we're the minority, the entitled few crying about our first world problems sometimes :)

comments.text:
I've one of those people that is always waiting for the next best thing to my detriment.  It means I'm still using a i7 4770k and a GTX 970 (upgraded from a GTX 770).  For a long time I've been able to play the games I want on at medium settings at 1080p so it hasn't been an issue after I upgraded to an SSD.  Now, though, I can't anymore.  Games and professional applications are killing both my CPU and GPU.  But the pricing on modern parts is causing massive sticker shock.  Sure, I COULD afford to buy the RTX 5080 which would be a massive upgrade to what I've got but $1000 for something that performs like a $1000 Nvidia card from two years ago and trades blows with a $900 AMD card from two years ago?  With greater total power consumption even if it's "more efficient"?  No thanks.

Then again, maybe I'm just a cheapskate and want the impossible: great GPU options around $500 again.

comments.text:
This isn't a novel idea, but my gut told me as soon as Jensen took the whole "Moore's Law is dead" tack that he was framing the conversation to build a narrative to support NVidia's future AI plans. I believe it's typical that manufacturers are already working on the next thing even as they release their "current" products. I think he knew then NVidia was planning to lean heavily into AI as the future of gaming GPUs, and the AI boom has only helped NVidia decide to double down on that approach. They have a knack for making bold statements and then not flinching or backing down as a tactic. As was touched on in the video, they weren't even willing to admit they had bad pricing for the 4080. They took the "We're not wrong, we'll just release another product that is what should have really been released to begin with and call it something else" approach (4080 Super). Didn't admit to anything.

I think a big reason we are seeing a generation like the 50 series is because NVidia likes proprietary approaches that they control. With their main revenue being enterprise AI solutions, if they can convince the consumer market that AI is THE way for the future of gaming, they can continue developing cutting edge AI software for enterprise and let all that R&D trickle down to consumer class products with little extra effort, and with minimal hardware costs and improvements. They win all around and move the narrative to software based solutions they control, and that are more subjective and harder to compare in an apples to apples way.

My main hope is that AMD and Intel will get their acts together and come out with at least reasonably competitive products to give consumers a choice before game developers and the industry fully embraces NVidia as the only "real" RT solution. I also hope consumers can avoid drinking the NVidia Kool-Aid long enough to give the market a chance to provide alternatives. I don't deny NVidia makes good products, but I think NVidia is very predatory and NEEDS competition for consumers to get a fair product. At least some options that are open source... I dread to think we are heading into an age where proprietary solutions may mean that to get optimal performance on game X you need a GPU from company Y that they partnered with because those are the only AI models they bothered to train with.
comments.author: @AlchemyfromAshes

comments.text:
Not an Intel CPU buyer since my last X-99 build, so while I admire your stamina in reviewing all those MB, I didn't watch it.  Your comment about 30 series holdouts struck me funny.  I was an EVGA 1080Ti FTW3 holdout until I chose a PowerColor HellHound 7900XTX.....and very happy with it.  Nothing I play or do using my 4K TV as my monitor has RT.  Didn't miss RT etc. on my 1080Ti and certainly do not miss RT, upscaling, etc. now.
GPU makers need to find out why so many 2g-6g Vram refuse to upgrade.  Referencing how many there seem to be via Steam* Survey.  Second:  Can GPU makers make a profit serving the low-ultra low end of the market?  Third:  People buy exotic cars and handbags with names, so for some, money is no object.  How "powerful" is good enough and at what price point?  My opinion is $500 to $600 maximum with 16g Vram minimum.  A performance level of 6900XT, 7900GRE, 4070 or 4070 Super.  For GPUs at this tier, RT is a pipe dream until the performance hit is reduced by at least half.  No marketing BS by using frame gen.
I play games for fun.  Why my PS2, SuperNintendo and X-Box are still in use as well as my PC.  Sure, I enjoy "pretty", but if the game sucks, who cares how "pretty" it is?  Black Myth 4K RT etc. enabled and a 5090 maybe gets 30 FPS? LMFAO.  A heck of a penalty and cost for "amazing" eye candy.

comments.text:
Prepare the performance/price analysis for the next QA once we get those 1300$ average 5080 prices. This to me is akin to the whole 4080 1200$ launch 'debacle'.

I was personally holding off on playing a few titles like Alan Wake 2, Cyberpunk and Black Myth Wukong because I wanted to experienced them at 4k with RT. I skipped  buying a 4080 because it wasn't good enough and the 4090 is too expensive. Putting my ceiling for a new gpu at around 1000$ I was looking to buy a 5080 (of course in a few months from now once the prices came back down and availability was improved) to get me in the 60-80fps at 4k RT range.


These results are very disappointing indeed. 
Alan Wake 2 - 34fps (4080s) to 38fps (5080),
Cyberpunk - 47fps (4080s) to 50fps (5080),
Black Myth Wukong  - 35fps (4080s) to 39fps (5080).

Getting an extra 3-5fps feels like something you'd get by tweaking settings and overclocking a gpu, not what you should get from a whole new generation. And now what? Wait another 2 years to spend the same 1000$ for another 5fps?

comments.text: So I'm a 3090 owner looking for a bit more performance on a 3840x1600 160hz display. I have no interest in spending 3090 money again, and considering 4090/5090 prices are above 2K, they aren't worth considering. Your benchmarks has the 5080 being 42% faster in non-RT, GN's had it being 55% faster in non-RT, I'll assume it's somewhere in the middle of that. GN had it being 69% (nice) faster in RT games than a 3090. Overall, I'm calling it a 50% increase for what is likely going to cost $1,200 with a 3rd party card. That's not great, but it's $600 less than the 3090 cost me. Overall, this is a really unsurprising result that isn't going to impress anyone on a 40 series card. For my specific use case, I think it's worth it to me. Consider me whelmed.

comments.text:
I have a 3080, and skipped 40 series card due to poor value.   Now according to Tech Power Up, the 5080 is representing a 66% uplift over a 3080, and I am not going to spend 2K USD on a 5090.  

It seems to me that my only realistic options are:
1. Try to find and buy a used 4090 while missing out on some of the latest features.  
2. Get a 5080 knowing it is faster, has more VRAM, the latest features and is not a massive power hog.  
3. Wait to see if 9070XT somehow actually represents a good performance boost over a 3080, and is somehow a much better value propoistion over a 5080.  I think that is a big if, as I would only consider this option if the performance ends up being at least 50% faster then a 3080, including ray tracing, and FSR 4 has to be damn good.

Every YouTuber who is disappointed they didn't get  huge increase is damaging their credibility.  With semiconductor lithography in the 3 to 5 nanometer range, did you honestly think that big gains were to be had here?  And if you did what are you basing this on other than .. "it happened in the past?"  Have you never heard the phrase "Past performance is not indicative of future success?"   Even if they had managed to use a newer, slightly smaller,TSMC fab process - the gains would not have been what you were expecting.  This is the NEW NORMAL.  gains in performance and power efficiency will continue to be harder to come by.

Are you really helping the "community" when the only part of this technology you understand is how to start up game, run a benchmark, and collect some data? comments.author: @TheRealPotoroo

comments.text: @TheRealPotoroo  80 tier cards used to be ~$600. $1000 is still a rip-off, even if it's technically better than $1200. Nvidia's intentional price creep over the past generations isn't an argument for a product that happens to just stagnation in price somehow not being disappointing. The performance improvement is nowhere near where a generational gain should be (not matching the previous higher tier? Not good enough), and failing to do so while still charging the same as the previous generation at the same tier is... yeah, just not worth buying. What's the point? It shows one out of 2 things: either Nvidia is actively running out of ways of improving gamign performance at acceptable price points, or they're artificially holding it back in order to drive up prices (through eroding customer expectations of value, like you're exemplifying here) going forward. While the former is likely true to some degree, it wouldn't make this any better of a purchase, and if the latter is true, that's just a scam.

comments.text:
I disagree with your reasoning. You don't get to pick and choose which GPU is successful or failed. It is what it is and you are engaging in cherry picking. You have to compare RTX 5080 to RTX 4080. If you want to compare it to RTX 4080 Super, then you have to accept that you are comparing to a half generation old GPU and thus you have to expect smaller performance margins. 

It was the same thing with RTX 2000 to 3000 series comparisons, except that time uplift was generally good for it not to matter. However, it still had significantly closed margins if you compared Super products to RTX 3000 series ones and it didn't looked all that impressive. Nvidia also compared them to original cards for better performance different that time too.

comments.text:
I feel the RTX 5080 is the reason why AMD delayed the RX 9070 XT.  Again, AMD is taking a new approach to R&D, where they are designing and making the chips, but they are not dropping them into production unless they can prove there is a customer to buy the products.  Lisa Su does not want another RX 6500 XT and RX 6400 where a ton of budget laptop GPUs were made before laptop manufacturers contracted to buy them for deep budget gaming laptops.  In this case, AMD cancelled the N41 and N42 due to failing in original design, but there is the unknown N43.  AMD was expecting the RTX 5080 to be closer to the RTX 4090 D in performance, but everyone recognized at CES the RTX 5080 presented was marginally better than the RTX 4080 Super.  From this, AMD decided to hold back the RX 9070 Series unveil to validate if they can release a true RX 9080 to break the RTX 5080, determine if they roll back the statement that AMD will not release a high end GPU.  The 2 months is enough time to do the necessary production tests and give a statement to commit to the RX 9080 Series, targetting end of 2025 release.

All of the boosts the RTX 5080 has in the benchmarks is a result of GDDR7, but apparently another limitation is holding the RTX 5080 back, preventing optimal usage of the VRAM bandwidth.  What truly went wrong for the RTX 50 Series is the "Boost Clock" uplift.

This really means if AMD made an RDNA4 refresh of Navi31 (RX 7900 Series) with the fixes, AMD could have delivered a powerful competitor in both raster and RT in a tier that is literally missing from Nvidia's line up.

comments.text:
@Hoacakes  I know, but in a synthetic test you could probably get these to be near a doubling. Game code and dispatching causes a lot of lost scaling ofc. But if you ran a game 99% on the gpu, even using it to solve for general computing, you would probably get close to that 100% scaling. But also at a total performance loss as forgoing the cpu for simple serial tasks is a bit odd. but would be cool.

I make gpu sculpting software, and we have gone completely away from the cpu so we see near 100% scaling with SM cores + clock speeds. That's really why i'm harping on about this. It would just be cool to see in games also.

comments.text:
Pathetic, but on the other hand, it performs pretty well considering it's a 5070 in all but its name.
To make things even worse, people will still happily buy this, since, truth to be told, it's technically a significant upgrade from a 3080 in all metrics for instance and the best 999$ GPU on the market - well, assuming one can find it at MSRP or near that to begin with. 
In fact, during writing this comment, I decided to make a one minute research, so let that sink: 3070 has more cores relative to 3090 (5888 vs 10496 -> 56%) than 5080 to 5090 (10752 vs 21760 -> 49%), the specs shrinkflation we're getting at this point is ridiculous, we might never 'escape Jensen'.
Basically, they released the new '4080 12GB' but without the real 5080 this time, so people don't get mad again - thus nVIDIA learning from their mistake.
They did this specifically because they also saw people didn't like paying 1200$ for a '80' class card so instead they now sell a 5070 one renamed as 5080 for just 999$ which looks a lot more digestable.

@ Perhaps, but we are talking like what 2 - 3 years from now? They won't be fully implemented as long as consoles can't do it in a reasonable way. And the PS6 won't be coming before the end of 2026.

I also don't buy most games on launch anyway (more like 2 years later during a Steam sale). So that's already 4 - 5 years on top of the year I've already gotten out of the 7900 XTX.

I would be more concerned about VRAM usage. Because developers love upping the resolution which means textures have to follow... 12gb is already on the limit now. 16gb will sooner rather than later be in that precarious situation. Add on top of that, the fact that RT is nice and all but it also eats VRAM. Sure NVIDIA cards are faster than AMD cards in RT, no doubt about it. But those 12gb and 16gb cards will also get bottlenecked by the time RT is mandatory.

comments.text: @chrisbeasley4727  The annoying aspect of modern GPU pricing and performance is that any actual architectural improvements gen to gen are overshadowed because so much of the performance is determined by how big of a die each class gets along with memory, memory bandwidth and power allowances. Nvidia could have made the 5080 a more interesting product by making it 75% of the 5090's stats at a $1500 price point. This 50% card would then become the 5070 Ti and every card down the line gets shifted one class accordingly. It would've created actual tiers between 70, 80, and 90 classes and allowed the 5080 to beat the previous gen's 90 class by 5-10%, which would make for a sensible structure. They learned nothing from the 4080 debacle it seems.
comments.author: @discrep

comments.text: @Kazuu7Str True or at worst, they were only on par, this feels like a 60 Ti class.
comments.author: @fabiusmaximuscunctator7390

comments.text:
@Kazuu7Str  The flagship has been changing gen to gen and along with some gens (the 20 series) being mediocre overall makes it difficult to find trends. The 3090 was the first modern 90 class, but it was basically a 3080 with more memory and wasn't popular among gamers. Even with that context, the 4070 only beats it in a few games at 1080p and is beaten by both 3090 and 3080 at 1440p and 4K pretty consistently.

That aside, my point is that Nvidia is in complete control of each class's performance because it's all about how much silicon they put onto the cards. It makes no sense where they have positioned the 80 class for the 40- and 50-series.

I think anyone getting excited for that is going to be underwhelmed.  Did everyone just memory hole CES? They literally had a chart showing where the 9700 series would land in comparison to the 7000 series and Nvidia's 4000 series. The 9700XT was lined up with the 7900XT and the 4070 ti. So, everyone needs to RELAX and realize even AMD is not marketing this thing as something that's going to compete with anything beyond the upper mid range. AMD has already told you what to expect. 
As far as pricing goes it's going to suck because AMD typically prices their cards based how they perform compared to Nvidia. If the 9700XT is around 4070ti performance and the 5070ti is going to slightly out perform a 4070ti super (a card already better than a 4070 ti) then my educated guess is the 9700XT will be $649. It'll perform right in between the 5070 and 5070ti and be priced accordingly. Maybe a little less or more depending on which of those two cards it's performance is closer to. 

Either way, it's going to be just OK, acceptable. Nothing to get excited about until it eventually goes on sale a year from now.

comments.text: @Aad77777  The biggest problem with AMD is not having anything close to DLSS. DLSS4 is out and it absolutely destroys current generation DLSS, which already destroys current generation FSR. Unless AMD's new FSR upscaling is revolutionarily better to be on par with DLSS4 - which is basically an impossibility - it will just keep lagging behind. This is not even considering the framegen performance gap. This channel keeps downplaying upscaling and relegating it to "features" but I feel at this point upscaling IS the way people play their games. If you are playing a game at 2k or 4k with native rendering, you probably have the top end card and the game must not be demanding. For nearly every other scenario people are using quality DLSS/FSR to upscale instead of using native resolution. With how terrible FSR is AMD is just going to keep losing market share.

comments.text:
@parowOOz  Ok, I'll have a word.

First of all, you got them mixed up. Titan Maxwell was "Geforce GTX TITAN X", while for Pascal you had "Nvidia Titan X" and "Nvidia Titan Xp". Very stupid name, I know.

The titan cards had:
- different branding and marketing
- extra features (pro drivers and NGX for example)
- full tensor speed (aka not artificially limited as for the non Titan cards)
- extra VRAM

3090 has literally one of the Titan features above: the extra VRAM. That's it. All the others are missing.

If you want more info search online for "The 3090 is not a Titan replacement and here is why"

So, no, 3090 is not comparable to Titan cards. Even so, the Titan cards didn't had over 100% extra pricing, except for Titan RTX. RTX 3090 is exceptionally bad value, including the Titan cards, only having competition from Titan RTX. 

Even if the value vs Titans wasn't worse for RTX 3090, it still doesn't have the different marketing. People buying RTX 3090 for pure gaming or using it in comparisons with the other gaming cards are just as bad (to say it nicely) as people buying or comparing a Titan card for pure gaming.

So everything I said in the first post still stands.
comments.author: @Winnetou17

​ @Dempig Fair, DLSS 4 (no frame Gen) is amazing in quality, and realistically for the review I've seen, would be impossible to spot while playing.

Honestly, if AMD actually wants to increase their market share, say 750$ for a 7900xtx. It would absolutely destroy Nvidia current gen. Dlss is amazing, RT is niche. But the average gamer would probably go for a 7900xtx instead of s 4080 super / 5080.
